name: Vladimiralexiev.github.io
body:
Here's what I got

# Getty AAT
Draft documentation of the AAT Semantic Representation for http://vocab.getty.edu. 

Official versions:
* PDF version:	http://www.getty.edu/research/tools/vocabularies/lod/aat_semantic_representation.pdf (for printing)
* HTML version:	http://www.getty.edu/research/tools/vocabularies/lod/aat/ (for linking), upcoming

# Ontotext Research Projects
[Ontotext-FP-projects-timeline.html](Ontotext-FP-projects-timeline.html) is the frame that displays the project timeline at http://www.ontotext.com/EC_ResearchProjects. It uses a Google Sheet and Google Charts

# SPARQL Syntax Diagrams
Syntax (rail-road) diagrams of SPARQL 1.1 Query Language. I use this quite often while writing SPARQL

* extracted from: http://www.w3.org/TR/sparql11-query/
* version: http://www.w3.org/TR/2013/REC-sparql11-query-20130321/
* created on: Tue Apr 2, 2013, 08:59 (UTC+03)
* created by: vladimir.alexiev at ontotext dot com
* created with: http://bottlecaps.de/rr/ui 
This tool is quite good: it can scrape EBNF grammars from W3C specs, generates either a single XHTML with embedded SVG, or a zip with many PNGs, cross-links the definitions and usages.

The files are:
* [sparql/sparql11-grammar.xhtml](sparql11-grammar.xhtml): Cross-linked diagrams, one per production (173 total). A bit hard to understand: use this for reference, but not for learning SPARQL.
* Here's a chunked diagram, which however is partial: http://ontologicalengineering.blogspot.com/2008/12/sparql-railroad-diagram-from-hell.html. (Discussion: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15758282/bigger-granularity-railroad-diagram-generator)
* [sparql/sparql11-grammar.ebnf](sparql11-grammar.ebnf): EBNF rules extracted from the spec
* [sparql/sparql11-grammar.txt](sparql11-grammar.txt): same thing but with production numbers
note: Don't delete this file! It's used internally to help with page regeneration.
